etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in Samuel Frederick Gray (1766–1828), naturalist and pharmacologist. From French †citronelle (now citronnelle), denoting any of various plants whose herbs have a strong lemony smell, liqueur flavoured with lemon peel from citron + -elle

definitions: A liqueur flavoured with lemon peel.
More fully "citronelle tea". A type of tea made from an infusion of lemongrass.
